content.title: Cilostazol Indications in PAD

definition.primary: A phosphodiesterase III inhibitor with vasodilatory and antiplatelet properties, FDA-approved for treatment of intermittent claudication in peripheral arterial disease, shown to improve walking distance by 40-50% compared to placebo.
key_concepts: Only FDA-approved medication for claudication symptoms
Dual mechanism: vasodilation and antiplatelet effects
Improves pain-free and maximal walking distance

mechanism_of_action.primary: Selective inhibition of phosphodiesterase type III (PDE3)

effects.mechanism: Increases cAMP in vascular smooth muscle, causes relaxation
Increases cAMP in platelets, inhibits aggregation
Reduces inflammatory mediators, may have antiproliferative effects

pharmacokinetics.bioavailability: High oral bioavailability, increased by fatty meal

walking_distance.improvement: 40-50% increase in maximal walking distance vs placebo
walking_distance.absolute_improvement: Average 50-70 meters improvement in pain-free walking

efficacy_data.quality_of_life: Significant improvement in claudication-specific quality of life measures

key_trials.finding: Consistent improvement in walking distance at 12-24 weeks

clinical_evidence.time_to_effect: Maximum benefit seen at 12 weeks, some improvement by 4-8 weeks
clinical_evidence.durability: Benefit maintained with continued therapy, symptoms return within 2-4 weeks of discontinuation

approved.evidence: Level A - multiple RCTs showing efficacy

patient_selection: Lifestyle-limiting claudication despite risk factor modification
Candidates for exercise therapy (often used as adjunct)
Patients who are not surgical/endovascular candidates

absolute.rationale: PDE3 inhibitors increase mortality in heart failure (milrinone class effect)

relative: Concomitant use with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors

standard.timing: 30 minutes before or 2 hours after breakfast and dinner
standard.rationale: Food increases absorption which may increase side effects

dose_adjustments.scenario: CYP3A4 or CYP2C19 inhibitors (omeprazole, diltiazem, ketoconazole)

dosing.duration: Continue indefinitely if tolerated and effective; trial discontinuation if revascularization performed

common.management: Often resolves with continued use, start at lower dose if severe

serious.context: Black box warning for heart failure

cyp3a4_inhibitors.examples: Ketoconazole, itraconazole, erythromycin, diltiazem, grapefruit juice

antiplatelet_anticoagulants.management: Monitor for bleeding, but combination with aspirin is common in PAD

vs_pentoxifylline.recommendation: Cilostazol preferred; pentoxifylline has marginal efficacy at best

vs_supervised_exercise.efficacy: Supervised exercise similar or superior improvement

practical_considerations.insurance_coverage: Generally covered, may require prior authorization
patient_counseling: Take on empty stomach for best tolerability
Headache common initially but usually improves
Allow 12 weeks for full effect before judging efficacy
Report symptoms of heart failure immediately

content.statement: Cilostazol Indications in PAD is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pharmacology that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Cilostazol Indications in PAD helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Cilostazol Indications in PAD include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Cilostazol Indications in PAD.

learning_objectives: Understand the mechanism of action of cilostazol
Identify appropriate candidates for cilostazol therapy
Apply dosing adjustments for drug interactions
Counsel patients on expected benefits and side effects
key_points: Only FDA-approved drug for intermittent claudication
Improves walking distance by 40-50% vs placebo
Absolutely contraindicated in heart failure (any class)
Common side effects (headache, diarrhea) often improve over time
clinical_pearls: Always screen for heart failure before prescribing
Reduce dose with omeprazole or diltiazem co-administration
Combine with supervised exercise for additive benefit
Taking on empty stomach reduces side effects
